Graphical abstract Inexpensive and reusable transition metal heterogeneous catalysts demonstrate excellent polybutadiene performance and are appealing substitutes for precious metal and homogeneous catalysts. Here, a variety of homogeneous nickel catalysts were designed and synthesized by a two-step Schiff base reaction involving dinaphthones and different aniline derivatives. These homogeneous nickel catalysts are also known as novel α-diimine ligands with asymmetric N-aryl substituents (Ni1-Ni3). Under the optimal reaction conditions ([BD]/[Ni] = 6000, [Al]/[Ni] = 600, 0 °C, 4 h), Ni3 exhibited the best catalytic effect (PBD yields obtained averaged 96.5 %). The PBD in question possesses a molecular weight of 5.53 × 104. The cis-structural ratio aligns with the Ziegler-Natta catalytic system. The corresponding heterogeneous nickel catalysts (Ni1/CNT-Ni3/CNT) were prepared by attaching these ligands to the carbon nanotube surfaces via amidation reactions of carboxyl and amino groups. Under the optimal conditions, Ni3/CNT exhibited the best catalytic effect (the obtained PBD yield reached 99.4 % on average). The PBD in question possess a molecular weight of 5.30 × 104. No significant decrease in activity was observed after five reuse cycles. The homogeneous catalyst (Ni3/CNT) prepared in this experiment not only improves production efficiency and economic benefits but also reduces energy consumption and environmental pollution. Keywords Homogeneous nickel catalysts Heterogeneous nickel catalysts Catalytic 1,3-butadiene polymerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Butadiene rubber has been extensively utilized worldwide due to its numerous advantages, including high elasticity and exceptional wear resistance. These properties have positioned it as a crucial raw material for the manufacturing of superior tires, sports equipment, medical devices, and a wide array of other products [1–6]. Over the last few decades, nickel-based catalyst systems have significantly contributed to the advancement of conjugated alkadiene polymerization processes [7–10]. In addition to achieving high polymerization efficiency, it is equally important to focus on the efficient recovery of catalysts during their utilization [11–17]. It is of practical importance to design and develop an efficient and reusable nickel catalyst for the preparation of butadiene rubber. In the development of nickel-based catalysts, α-diimine nickel catalysts have gained considerable attention due to their exceptional activity and selectivity [18]. In recent years, various research groups have conducted a series of ligand explorations to obtain α-diimine nickel catalysts with desired properties [19,20]. Modifying the N-aryl group has proven to be a promising strategy for enhancing the polymerization activity of olefins. This strategy includes increasing the axial space volume of the N-aryl group and introducing additional heteroatoms with electronic effects into ligands [21–23]. However, these catalysts are mainly homogeneous catalysts with slight deficiencies in catalyst separation, recovery, stability and catalytic efficiency. To overcome these shortcomings, the researchers proposed preparing heterogeneous catalysts prepared by loading homogeneous α-diimide nickel complexes with asymmetric N-aryl substituents on carbon nanotubes for 1,3-butadiene polymerization catalysts. During the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts, researchers investigated different methods and carriers to achieve optimal results. The commonly chosen carriers include SiO2 [24–26], Al2O3 [27], MgCl2 [28], Fe3O4 [29], carbon materials [30], polymers [31], and others. The preparation methods encompassed impregnation [32], co-precipitation [33], and chemical bonding [34–36]. By using the above strategies, numerous challenges in the olefin polymerization process could be simultaneously resolved. The synergistic interplay between the carrier and catalyst significantly enhanced polymerization activity, while facilitating effective control over polymer morphology and minimizing reactor contamination [37–40]. The strategic selection of a catalyst carrier and optimal loading mode could significantly enhance both the catalyst utilization rate and the efficiency of olefin polymerization [41], thereby enabling the realization of a sustainable and eco-friendly production mode [42,43]. Our objective was to innovate a nickel catalyst featuring α-diimine ligands, which could be effectively anchored to the support through robust chemical bonding. This strategy not only facilitated the catalyst's reusability but also enhanced its overall catalytic performance. Based on this premise, we have developed and synthesized a range of homogeneous nickel catalysts (innovative α-diimine ligands with asymmetric N-aryl substituents) through a two-step Schiff base reaction of dinaphthone and various aniline derivatives. Interestingly, all these ligands feature an accessible amino group, which can be transformed into corresponding homogeneous nickel catalysts through amidation reaction with carboxyl groups linked to the carbon nanotube surface. These homogeneous nickel catalysts exhibited outstanding performance in catalyzing the polymerization of 1,3-butadiene. With the added benefits of easy separation and recyclability, reduced environmental impact, and compliance with green chemistry principles, these homogeneous nickel catalysts hold promising prospects for applications in the chemical industry. 2 Experimental 2.1 Technological route As shown in Scheme 1 , during the preparation of Ni1-Ni3, we sequentially synthesized the ligands a1-a3 and b1-b3 through a two-step Schiff base reaction involving bisnaphthone and various aniline derivatives. Subsequently, the corresponding nickel complexes were prepared via ultrasonic reaction, where the ligands b1-b3 coordinated with Ni(DME)Cl2. The 1H NMR spectrum of the six synthesized ligands (a1-a3, b1-b3) is presented in the Supporting Information. In order to facilitate the preparation of a heterogeneous nickel catalyst, we chose MwCNT-COOH as the catalyst carrier, with a carboxyl content of 3.9 wt%. The interaction between the homogeneous catalyst and the support was achieved through the amidation of the carboxyl and amino groups. This support method offers significant advantages in terms of catalyst recyclability. The preparation process of Ni/CNT as shown in Scheme 2 , we initially activated the carboxyl group on the carrier using EDC (1-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide) and HBT (1-hydroxybenzotriazole). Subsequently, the heterogeneous catalyst was prepared by directly incorporating the synthesized nickel complex (Ni1-Ni3) into the system. The separation and recovery of the heterogeneous catalyst were easily accomplished through a simple PVDF filter membrane filtration process. The catalyst was subsequently rinsed, dried, and ready for use in subsequent reactionsteps. 2.2 Experimental process 2.2.1 Synthesis of a1-a3 a1: Acenaphthenone (601 mg, 3.30 mmol) and a catalytic amount of p-toluenesulfonic acid were dissolved in DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide) (20.0 mL) at 80 °C. The relevant samples were obtained after fully washed with DCM (3 × 20.0 mL) then dried. 2.2.5 Polymerization of 1,3-butadiene Under the nitrogen atmosphere, the 1,3-butadiene and EASC (ethylaluminum sesquichloride) were injected into containing the toluene solutions of nickel catalysts, as shown in Table 1 . After a period of time, the polymerization was terminated by 5 vol% HCl(aq)/ethanol solution.The polymers were washed with ethanol and dried. Experimental conditions for reuse of heterogeneous catalysts were as the best ones of homogeneous catalysts. The supported catalyst was recovered by filtration method, treated with 5 vol% HCl(aq)/THF solution, vacuum dried, and put into the next reaction. The experiment was repeated five times for each group of polymerization. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization and property of homogeneous catalysts (Ni1-Ni3) The catalytic performance of α-diimine transition metal catalysts is influenced by different ligands in various ways. In conventional olefin polymerization, nickel catalysts typically exist as Ni(Ⅱ) or Ni(Ⅳ), with the coordination of the nickel center significantly affecting reactivity. However, Ni(Ⅵ), due to its higher oxidation potential, can activate and polymerize olefins under milder reaction conditions. In this study, we investigated the catalytic performance of Ni1-Ni3 under various conditions including [BD]/[Ni], [Al]/[Ni], temperature (T), and reaction time for 1,3-butadiene polymerization (scheme 3 ). Here, different ratios of 1,3-butadiene to the catalyst were examined to determine the optimal results. Due to the limited space of the article and the similar trends observed in the polymerization experiments for Ni1, Ni2, and Ni3, only Ni3 was specifically analyzed. First, Table 1 (No. 23–27) shows that the yield tends to increase and then decrease, peaking at [BD]/[Ni] equal to 6000. In terms of activity, we find that the activity is similar at [BD]/[Ni] ratios of 8000 and 10000, with only a slight increase in activity compared to the [BD]/[Ni] ratio of 6000. Additionally, the increase in [BD]/[Ni] corresponds to the increase in molecular weight. Considering the environmentally friendly use of monomer raw materials, we chose [BD]/[Ni] = 6000 as the fixed condition for subsequent experiments. Then, we explored the effects of [Al]/[Ni] ratios (Table 1, No. 25, 28 and 29). Unfortunately, no reliable data could be obtained at [Al]/[Ni] = 200. When [Al]/[Ni] increased to 1000, the polymer yield improved, but the molecular weight decreased. In the temperature experiment (Table 1, No. 25, 30, and 31), we found that polymerization yield and molecular weight were greatly improved at a reaction temperature of 0 °C. This enhancement could be attributed to the low boiling point of 1,3-butadiene, which increased monomer solubility in the solvent at 0 °C, thereby enhancing reaction efficiency. Finally, we investigated the effect of reaction time on polymerization (Table 1, No. 30, 32 and 33). A reaction time of 2 h was insufficient for complete reaction, while extending it to 4 h resulted in peak reaction efficiency. Prolonging the reaction time to 6 h did not significantly improve the reaction efficiency compared to 4 h. Overall, the catalytic efficiency of the catalysts was highest when [BD]/[Ni] = 6000, [Al]/[Ni] = 600, the reaction temperature was 0 °C, and the reaction time was 4 h. By summarizing the polymerization effects of the three catalysts (Ni1-Ni3) under the optimal polymerization conditions in Table 1, we found that the Ni3 catalyst, with a significant hindering effect, exhibited the most effective catalytic performance, as indicated by the highest yield and molecular weight (Fig. 1 ). The infrared spectrum of PBD (Table 1, No. 30) was shown on Fig. 2 (a). The peaks at 967.42 cm−1 and 736.56 cm−1 corresponded to ʋ (trans-C–C) and ʋ (cis-C–C). The TG of PBD (Fig. 2 (b)) was relatively smooth and fast, which proves that the structure of the polymer was relatively uniform. It remained stable at 350 °C. The obtained PBD (Table 1, No. 30) was characterized by 13C NMR (Fig. 2 (c)). The absorption peaks at δ27.43 ppm and δ29.71 ppm corresponded to ʋ (cis-C–C) and ʋ (trans-C–C). According to the above spectrum, it could be proved that PBD with ultra-high proportion of cis-structure (93.3 %) obtained by the series of catalysts in this paper. The polymerization of 1,3-butadiene would follow Ziegler-Natta rule. The related XPS spectra of ligand b3, Ni(DME)Cl2 and catalyst Ni3 were shown in Fig. 3 . In the full spectrum (Fig. 3(a)), four characteristic peaks appeared in 196.5 eV, 284.8 eV, 398.7 eV and 856.1 eV, corresponded to Cl2p, C1s, N1s and Ni2p respectively. This phenomenon confirms that the catalyst Ni3 contained Cl, C, N and Ni elements. The C1s comparison spectra of ligand b3 and catalyst Ni3 were shown in Fig. 3(b). Since the central atom of Ni metal mainly reacts with the N atom, it could be found that the peak shape of C element in the sample changes little before and after the coordination reaction. The N1s contrast spectra of ligand b3 and catalyst Ni3 were shown in Fig. 3(c). After peak fitted of the two samples, ligand b3 showed two characteristic peaks, namely C-N = C at 396.7 eV and C-NH2 at 397.3 eV. Three characteristic peaks appeared in the N1s map of catalyst Ni3, which were N-Ni, C-NH2 and C-N = C at 399.9 eV, 399.3 eV and 398.7 eV. By comparison, it could be found that the peak intensity of C-N = C decreased after the coordination, and N-Ni appears after the coordination which did not exist before the coordination. The reason for the decrease of the peak intensity of C-N = C binding energy was that Ni metal atom was involved, which leaded to the change of the original functional group electron cloud density in the ligand. It could be seen from Fig. 3(c) that N-Ni binding energy appeared, and due to the coordination reaction between N atom and Ni central metal atom, the peak position of binding energy of N element was greatly shifted as a whole. The occurrence of coordination reaction was proved by the change of N element above. The Ni2p correlation spectra of Ni(DME)Cl2 and catalyst Ni3 were shown in Fig. 3(d). The peaks of the Ni2p spectra of catalyst Ni3 at 874.1 eV and 856.4 eV correspond to the binding energies of Ni2p1/2 and Ni2p3/4. It was found that the binding energy of Ni2p1/2 and Ni2p3/2 with Ni(DME)Cl2 was similarity. For the Ni metal center atom, the addition of ligands means that the coordination atom changes from O atom to N atom, and the electronegativity difference between the two coordination atoms was small, so the change of Ni2p in Fig. 3(d) was small. We cultivated complex Ni3 single crystals in DCM/hexane solvent and conducted SC-XRD under low-temperature conditions. In Fig. 4 (a), the finding that a nickel center with two ligand binding was proved, was different from previous reports [22,44,45]. Due to the presence of chlorine atoms, the four nitrogen and nickel were in a unified plane, Ni-Cl was perpendicular to this plane, and the Ni(Ⅵ) were octahedral. The large steric isopropyl structure of the ligand hindered the achievement of the mirror symmetry structure in the nickel complex, but promoted a center symmetry structure. Consequently, the ligands' coordination direction naturally adjusted towards the nickel center, stabilizing the ligand ensemble surrounding the nickel center. After obtaining the crystal structure of catalyst Ni3, we performed it by SambVca 2.1 procedure [46–48]. The buried volume parameter (%Vbur) was calculated to obtain SW%Vbur = 72.2, SE%Vbur = 69.8, NE%Vbur = 72.2, NW%Vbur = 69.8, as shown in Fig. 2(b,c). It was proved that the “double ligand” structure of Ni3 catalyst makes the steric hindrance around the central atom of Ni larger. It provides a theoretical basis for the steric hindrance effect of ligands in the subsequent catalytic polymerization of 1,3-butadiene. By further comparing the electrostatic potential maps of Ni1 to Ni3 in Fig. 5 (a-c), we observe that the region of negative charge on the Ni atom at the molecular center becomes increasingly narrow, indicating a growing steric hindrance effect at the molecular center. From the surface distribution maps of the electrostatic potential across different ranges for Ni1 to Ni3, as shown in Fig. 5(d),we find no significant differences in the electrostatic potential distribution on the molecules; however, there are some variations in the range of −15 to −5 kcal/mol, which gradually increase from Ni1 to Ni3. These differences arise from the increasing electrostatic potential distribution associated with the added alkyl groups from Ni1 to Ni3. Based on this analysis, we can conclude that the increase in activity from Ni1 to Ni3 is attributed to the enhanced steric hindrance. 3.2 Characterization and property of heterogeneous catalysts (Ni1/CNT-Ni3/CNT) After investigating the experimental performance of these homogeneous nickel catalysts in the polymerization of 1,3-butadiene, we prepared a series of heterogeneous nickel catalysts based on this research. The SEM image of MwCNT-COOH is shown in Fig. 6 (a). The SEM images of Ni3/CNT are shown in Fig. 6(b). Upon comparison, it is evident that the morphology of the support remains unchanged before and after the catalyst is supported; it still retains its loose and porous characteristics. Fig. 6(c-g) show the element mapping of Ni3/CNT, illustrating the uniform distribution of the Ni3 catalyst on the support. The study utilized three heterogeneous catalysts (catalyst dosage based on 2 wt% nickel content) were used in the polymerization reaction of 1,3-butadiene under optimal catalytic conditions for homogeneous catalysts. An unexpected discovery was made that these heterogeneous catalysts effectively addressed the limitations of homogeneous catalysts in terms of recyclability, maintaining consistent catalytic performance over five cycles (Fig. 7 (a-c)). Furthermore, the polymerization yields achieved with the heterogeneous nickel catalysts were notably higher compared to those with homogeneous nickel catalysts, primarily attributed to their uniform distribution. The immobilization of the homogeneous nickel catalysts by carrier can effectively prevent bonding between them. Moreover, the presence of an amide bond in the heterogeneous catalyst acts as a strong electron-donating group, enhancing the stability of the Ziegler-Natta system and facilitating the reaction. A comparative evaluation of the catalytic efficiencies of the three heterogeneous nickel catalysts is depicted in Fig. 7(d), indicating that Ni3/CNT exhibited the most favorable polymerization outcomes in terms of yield and molecular weight. This was characterized by a PBD yield of 99.4 % and molecular weight (Mw) and molecular weight distribution (PDI) of 5.30 × 104 and 4.68, respectively. Furthermore, it was noted that the catalytic efficiency of Ni3/CNT surpassed that of traditional noble metal catalysts in the identical application, as detailed in Table 2 for specific comparative data. 4 Conclusion In this research, three distinct homogeneous catalysts, namely novel α-diimine ligands featuring asymmetric N-aryl substituents (Ni1-Ni3), were successfully synthesized. The corresponding heterogeneous nickel catalysts (Ni1/CNT-Ni3/CNT) were synthesized by binding these ligands to the surfaces of carbon nanotubes through amidation reactions involving carboxyl and amino groups. PBD could be polymerized best by Ni3 as an average yield of 96.5 % and Mw of 5.53 × 104 with a high cis-structural ratios in accordance with the Ziegler-Natta catalyzed system. Ni3/CNT exhibited the most favorable catalytic outcomes under the optimal conditions. This was characterized by a PBD yield of 99.4 % and Mw and PDI of 5.30 × 104 and 4.68, respectively. The high efficiency and stability demonstrated by Ni3/CNT in the polymerization of 1,3-butadiene, as there was no significant decline in activity observed even after five reuse cycles, along with its potential applications in environmental protection and energy sectors, indicate promising prospects for its development. coredata.dc:description: Inexpensive and reusable transition metal heterogeneous catalysts demonstrate excellent polybutadiene performance and are appealing substitutes for precious metal and homogeneous catalysts. Here, a variety of homogeneous nickel catalysts were designed and synthesized by a two-step Schiff base reaction involving dinaphthones and different aniline derivatives. These homogeneous nickel catalysts are also known as novel α-diimine ligands with asymmetric N-aryl substituents (Ni1-Ni3). Under the optimal reaction conditions ([BD]/[Ni] = 6000, [Al]/[Ni] = 600, 0 °C, 4 h), Ni3 exhibited the best catalytic effect (PBD yields obtained averaged 96.5 %). The PBD in question possesses a molecular weight of 5.53 × 104. The cis-structural ratio aligns with the Ziegler-Natta catalytic system. The corresponding heterogeneous nickel catalysts (Ni1/CNT-Ni3/CNT) were prepared by attaching these ligands to the carbon nanotube surfaces via amidation reactions of carboxyl and amino groups. Under the optimal conditions, Ni3/CNT exhibited the best catalytic effect (the obtained PBD yield reached 99.4 % on average). The PBD in question possess a molecular weight of 5.30 × 104. No significant decrease in activity was observed after five reuse cycles. The homogeneous catalyst (Ni3/CNT) prepared in this experiment not only improves production efficiency and economic benefits but also reduces energy consumption and environmental pollution.

coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous catalysts prepared by loading homogeneous α-diimide nickel complexes with asymmetric N-aryl substituents onto carbon nanotubes for 1,3-butadiene polymerization
